entry.title: Op-ed: Democrats should be courting Romney, not Manchin

link.title: Op-ed: Democrats should be courting Romney, not Manchin

entry.content:
Read the op-ed in The Hill

In a new op-ed, I argue that Democrats are more likely to pass cash assistance in reconciliation with Senator Mitt Romney as the 50th vote than with Senator Joe Manchin. Unlike Manchin, Romney supports a fully refundable Child Tax Credit, and has proposed a plan to achieve it called the Family Security Act. My UBI Center analysis of the Family Security Act shows that it would be progressive and effective, largely by virtue of its near-universality among children. And while Manchin has opposed multiple carbon pricing proposals, Romney supports a carbon dividend, a small UBI funded by fees on polluting corporations. In a separate UBI Center analysis, I showed that a carbon dividend would reduce poverty as well as emissions.

You can read the full op-ed in The Hill.
entry.summary: On the issues of child poverty and climate change, Democrats have a closer ally across the aisle.

entry.title: The American Rescue Plan was a step toward universal basic income

link.title: The American Rescue Plan was a step toward universal basic income

entry.content:
Read the op-ed here

In my latest op-ed, I argue that cash assistance policies (the expanded Child Tax Credit and $1,400 checks) were some of the most popular and effective parts of the American Rescue Plan; that they would have been even better if closer to universal basic income; and that we should double down on those cash successes with a permanent child allowance and carbon dividend. You can read it at The Hill.

Thanks to Joshua Miller for research assistance.
entry.summary: My latest op-ed argues that cash assistance was the key to the American Rescue Plan's success.
